@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 In short, your intellectually dishonest attempts to smear Obama are quite obvious and unconvincing. Try harder.
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 And that slow GDP growth is rather irrelevant to workers, who have seen strong recovery in wages and jobs.
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 But let's just note that, globally, the US is doing much stronger than the Eurozone.
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 That's without noting that the writer for the Forbes article is wrong, consensus is that retirement is major cause.
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 And more young adults than before have been going to university, thus not in the labour force.
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 There's this amazing thing called "university" where you can learn that a single Forbes article is a weak argument.
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 That is not what your article says, but okay let's deal with that as well, because this is a demographic trend.
@JBLADES13 Yes, also not related. Economists have studied this extensively, there's no casual link.
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 you are aware that every nation has had slow GDP growth coming out of the recession, correct?
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 I know y'all hate acknowledging that a black man is the most successful president in recent history, but deal.
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 yeah this false too. Retired =/= unemployed, nor can one redefine the method used to track unemployment.
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 Conflating retirement of the baby boomer generation with policies of Obama is dishonest and unethical.
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 also this is a flat lie. Labour force participation has been falling since Bush 43 because of demographics.
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 or did you forget that it was McConnell who decided to oppose all his policies?
@JBLADES13 @grimsley1999 I'm very sorry y'all crusty asses decided you didn't want healthcare, but it isn't his fault

Well of course they are. They fight groups and individuals that peddle hatred of minorities, like @realDonaldTrumpâ€¦ https://t.co/u6Y6l19rxH
As that requires a further very difficult to defend premise that religious beliefs are sufficient grounds for legislation affecting others.
/Even/ assuming that marriage is defined by God to be one man and one woman, there's still not a moral justification.
As to the other question, are those who oppose gay marriage automatically evil: no, but there is also no moral justification for doing so.
It is a hatred that jointly fails to bring in new members of the church /and/ fails to eradicate sin.
Which means that at no point will they, as we are holding to be true, abandon their sinful ways. It's a compound failure.
Because all that does, assuming those are true, is prevent those who are homosexual from being welcome in the church.
It is /still/ true, with those assumptions, that demonizing homosexuality should not be the purpose of the church or a main focus.
Let us, for a moment, assume that everything they claim is true: homosexuality is a sin, unnatural, and people can "stop" being gay.
And, to the other (what should be obvious) point: that is pretty damn far from the purpose of the church.
But it's still expressing some visceral antipathy toward a group regardless the justification.
Perhaps we don't care. Hatred of certain groups is perhaps moral - Nazis, murders, the like - or at least justifiable.
One can dress it up in various fashions to make it sound nicer, but it remains hatred at a foundational level.
Let us begin with the obvious: believing that homosexuality is a sin is indisputably hatred. It is a hatred of homosexuality by definition.
